Show HN: Easier Setup for Stephen Marz's “RISC-V OS in Rust” Series
text:
Hi HN, I was very excited to work through Stephen Marz's amazing "Adventures of OS: Making a RISC-V Operating System using Rust" series [1] but I had a difficult time getting everything set up. I created this starter repo [2] in the hopes that it will make it easier for others to get going. Question/comments/feedback/issues/PRs welcome.

[1] https://osblog.stephenmarz.com

[2] https://github.com/kaycebasques/rust-riscv64-qemu-starter

“The Shining” – I asked ChatGPT to put itself in Danny's shoes
text:
Can you put yourself in Danny's shoes?

As an AI language model, I do not have the ability to experience emotions or put myself in someone else's shoes in the way that humans do. However, I can try to imagine what it might be like to be in Danny's situation based on the information provided in the movie.

Danny is a young boy who has psychic abilities that allow him to see the hotel's dark past and the violent events that occurred there. He is also aware of the growing danger posed by his father's increasingly unstable behavior, but feels powerless to stop it.

If I were to try to imagine what it would be like to be in Danny's shoes, I might feel scared, vulnerable, and overwhelmed by the intense emotions and violent events happening around me. I might feel isolated and alone, with nobody to turn to for help. At the same time, I might also feel a sense of responsibility to try to protect myself and others from the danger posed by my father and the hotel's supernatural forces.

Show HN: IaSQL – Open-source tool to manage cloud infra as data in PostgreSQL
text:
Hi all,

IaSQL maintains a two-way connection between an unmodified PostgreSQL database and an AWS account. IaSQL at it's core is a diffing system between the cloud infrastructure state and the desired state that is used to execute AWS SDK calls to update your infrastructure.

But we also use the same mechanism to take changes in your infrastructure, perhaps made via the AWS console or an IaC tool like Terraform, and pull that into your IaSQL database. We use an audit log tracking who made changes where to determine which way the synchronization process goes, and this gives us a lot of "powers" over normal IaC.

First, you can inspect the tables in IaSQL and be sure that it's actually the state of our cloud (within a few minutes of difference), so you can be more sure that the changes you're writing up are likely to work.

Second, the changes you write are SQL statements to mutate your infrastructure rather than editing a declaration file, which is a different mental model vs IaC. But you gain from the constraints and foreign key relations on tables to catch mistakes in configuration before execution even happens to a greater degree than IaC tools can as this is like a "type safety" on top of dynamic information (other tables you depend on).

Third, you can enter an IaSQL transaction (slightly different from a normal Postgres transaction as you can't hook function calls on `BEGIN` and `COMMIT`) to make these changes and inspect what IaSQL will do like you can with IaC tools, but if there is a failure, the `iasql_commit` will take the information from the audit log and roll back the changes that were applied by applying the prior versions in reverse, so IaSQL should always be in a working state.

Finally, (since this is getting long) the live-infra data model of IaSQL makes dynamic infrastructure much simpler (eg, you deploy isolated instances of your services per customer) -- anything with a SQL client and credentials for the IaSQL database can connect and initiate these changes, which can be Postgres stored procedures you write and added to the database.

We're in beta so our coverage is not as large as existing IaC tools, but we now cover 25 different AWS services with our modules: https://iasql.com/docs/modules/ But please let us know if there's something you use that's missing. :)

Show HN: Dixit lets you search quotes close to your idea [Semantic quote search]
text:
[LLM-based semantic search meets historical quotes] Hello HN,

Want to sound smart, impress a date, get the right quotation to introduce this essay? Dixit lets you type an idea, and searches for historical quotations that roughly convey the the same idea, but probably in a cooler formulation + with the authority stamp of someone who has a Wikipedia page.

I built it over the 3 last weekends (and a few nights). It was quite fun! Dixit uses 25,000 quotations, a light language model from HuggingFace hub, Django, Railway server, and some CSS animations that I find cool. The code is available at http://github.com/A-Roucher/dixit.

Next thing I'll do is keep improving the database to remove some quotes and add many more. Please don't hesitate to propose improvements!
